topics.title: Ischemic Heart Disease
keyPoints: Risk factors: HTN, DM, smoking, dyslipidemia, family history, obesity, sedentary lifestyle
Pathophysiology: Atherosclerotic plaque formation → coronary artery narrowing → myocardial ischemia
Clinical presentation: Chest pain (crushing, radiating to left arm/jaw), dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea
Diagnosis: ECG (ST changes, T wave inversion), Cardiac biomarkers (Troponin I/T, CK-MB), Coronary angiography (gold standard)
STEMI: ST elevation >1mm in 2 contiguous leads, requires immediate reperfusion
NSTEMI: Elevated troponins without ST elevation, managed with antiplatelet therapy
Unstable angina: Ischemic symptoms without biomarker elevation
Acute management: MONA (Morphine, Oxygen, Nitrates, Aspirin) + Dual antiplatelet therapy
Reperfusion: Primary PCI (preferred if <90 min) or Thrombolysis (if PCI not available)
Secondary prevention: Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor, Beta-blockers, ACE inhibitors, Statins, Lifestyle modification

mnemonics.MONA: Initial MI management - Morphine (pain), Oxygen (if hypoxic), Nitrates (vasodilation), Aspirin (antiplatelet)
mnemonics.HEART: Risk stratification - History, ECG, Age, Risk factors, Troponin
mnemonics.TIMI: Thrombolysis contraindications - Time >12hrs, Intracranial pathology, Major surgery, Ischemic stroke

clinicalPearls: Silent MI common in diabetics and elderly due to autonomic neuropathy
Posterior MI shows ST depression in V1-V3, check posterior leads (V7-V9)
Right ventricular MI: Inferior MI + hypotension + clear lungs, avoid nitrates
Women may present with atypical symptoms: fatigue, nausea, back pain
Door-to-balloon time should be <90 minutes for STEMI

practiceQuestions.question: A 55-year-old male with diabetes presents with crushing chest pain radiating to left arm for 2 hours. ECG shows ST elevation in leads II, III, aVF. BP is 90/60 mmHg with clear lung fields. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
practiceQuestions.explanation: This is inferior wall MI with likely RV involvement (hypotension + clear lungs). RV infarction is preload-dependent, so IV fluids are needed. Nitrates are contraindicated as they reduce preload and can cause severe hypotension.

practiceQuestions.question: A 60-year-old smoker presents with chest pain for 6 hours. ECG shows ST depression in V2-V4. Troponin I is elevated. What is the diagnosis?
practiceQuestions.explanation: NSTEMI is characterized by elevated cardiac biomarkers (troponin) with ECG changes that do not meet STEMI criteria. ST depression and T wave inversion are common findings.

practiceQuestions.question: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy?
practiceQuestions.explanation: Recent ischemic stroke within 3 months is an absolute contraindication to thrombolysis due to high risk of hemorrhagic transformation. Age >75, uncontrolled HTN, and pregnancy are relative contraindications.

topics.title: Heart Failure
keyPoints: Definition: Inability of heart to pump sufficient blood to meet metabolic demands
Classification: HFrEF (EF <40%, systolic dysfunction) vs HFpEF (EF >50%, diastolic dysfunction)
NYHA functional classification: I (no symptoms), II (symptoms with moderate activity), III (symptoms with minimal activity), IV (symptoms at rest)
Common causes: IHD, HTN, valvular disease, cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias
Clinical features: Dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, pedal edema, fatigue, S3 gallop, elevated JVP
Diagnosis: Clinical assessment + BNP/NT-proBNP (>400 pg/mL) + Echocardiography (EF assessment)
Acute management: Oxygen, IV diuretics (furosemide), vasodilators (nitrates), treat underlying cause
Chronic HFrEF management: ACE-I/ARB + Beta-blocker + MRA (spironolactone) + SGLT2i + Diuretics
Device therapy: CRT (for LBBB + EF <35%), ICD (for EF <35% with high SCD risk)
Advanced therapy: LVAD (bridge to transplant), Heart transplantation (end-stage HF)

mnemonics.FACES: Common causes - Failure (pump), Arrhythmia, Coronary disease, Endocrine, Septal defects
mnemonics.ABCD: HF management - ACE-I/ARB, Beta-blocker, aldosterone antagonist (MRA), Diuretics
mnemonics.CHAMP: Decompensation triggers - Cardiac (MI, arrhythmia), Hypertension, Anemia, Medication non-compliance, Pulmonary embolism

clinicalPearls: BNP <100 pg/mL essentially rules out HF (high negative predictive value)
Start beta-blockers only after stabilization, not in acute decompensation
Spironolactone improves mortality in NYHA III-IV HFrEF
HFpEF management focuses on treating comorbidities (HTN, AF, DM)
Avoid NSAIDs and CCBs (except amlodipine) in HF patients

practiceQuestions.question: A 65-year-old with known HFrEF (EF 30%) presents with acute dyspnea, bilateral crackles, and BP 160/100. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
practiceQuestions.explanation: Acute decompensated HF with pulmonary edema requires IV loop diuretics (furosemide) for rapid diuresis and IV nitrates for preload reduction and BP control. Beta-blockers should not be started during acute decompensation.

practiceQuestions.question: Which medication has been shown to reduce mortality in HFrEF?
practiceQuestions.explanation: Spironolactone (MRA) has proven mortality benefit in HFrEF, especially in NYHA III-IV. Digoxin improves symptoms but not mortality. Furosemide is for symptom control. Amlodipine is safe but doesn't reduce mortality.

topics.title: Hypertension
keyPoints: Definition: BP ≥140/90 mmHg on 2 separate occasions (ACC/AHA: ≥130/80)
Classification: Stage 1 (140-159/90-99), Stage 2 (≥160/100), Hypertensive emergency (≥180/120 with organ damage)
Primary HTN (95%): Essential, multifactorial etiology
Secondary HTN (5%): Renal disease, renovascular, endocrine (Conn's, Cushing's, pheochromocytoma), drugs, coarctation
Target organ damage: LVH, retinopathy, nephropathy, stroke, CAD
Lifestyle modifications: DASH diet, salt restriction (<2g/day), weight loss, exercise, limit alcohol
First-line drugs: ACE-I/ARB, CCB, Thiazide diuretics
Compelling indications: DM/CKD (ACE-I/ARB), Post-MI (Beta-blocker + ACE-I), HF (ACE-I + BB + MRA)
Hypertensive emergency: Reduce BP by 25% in first hour, then to 160/100 in 2-6 hours using IV agents
Resistant HTN: Add spironolactone, screen for secondary causes

mnemonics.ABCD: Antihypertensive classes - ACE-I/ARB, Beta-blocker, CCB, Diuretic
mnemonics.CHARMS: Secondary HTN causes - Coarctation, Hyperaldosteronism, Renal artery stenosis, Medications, Sleep apnea

clinicalPearls: White coat HTN: Elevated in clinic, normal at home (confirm with ABPM)
Masked HTN: Normal in clinic, elevated at home (higher CV risk)
ACE-I preferred in DM/CKD for renoprotection
Avoid beta-blockers as first-line in uncomplicated HTN
Check for postural hypotension in elderly before intensifying treatment

practiceQuestions.question: A 45-year-old diabetic with HTN and proteinuria. Which antihypertensive is most appropriate?
practiceQuestions.explanation: ACE inhibitors (lisinopril) are first-line in diabetic nephropathy due to renoprotective effects beyond BP control. They reduce proteinuria and slow CKD progression.

topics.title: Asthma
keyPoints: Chronic inflammatory airway disease with reversible airflow obstruction and bronchial hyperresponsiveness
Triggers: Allergens (dust, pollen), exercise, cold air, infections, NSAIDs, beta-blockers, stress
Pathophysiology: Type 1 hypersensitivity → mast cell degranulation → bronchospasm, inflammation, mucus production
Clinical features: Episodic wheeze, dyspnea, chest tightness, cough (worse at night/early morning)
Diagnosis: Spirometry showing FEV1/FVC <70% with reversibility >12% (or >200mL) post-bronchodilator
Peak flow variability >20% supports diagnosis
Step-wise management: Step 1 (SABA PRN) → Step 2 (+ low-dose ICS) → Step 3 (+ LABA) → Step 4 (medium-dose ICS/LABA) → Step 5 (high-dose + add-ons)
Acute exacerbation: Oxygen, nebulized SABA + ipratropium, systemic steroids, IV magnesium if severe
Severe asthma: Silent chest, inability to speak, RR >30, HR >120, PEFR <33% predicted
Good control: Minimal symptoms, normal activity, PEFR >80% predicted, rare exacerbations

mnemonics.ASTHMA: Triggers - Allergens, Smoke, Temperature, Hormones, Meds (NSAIDs), Activity
mnemonics.SABA: Acute management - Salbutamol, Assess severity, Beta-agonist nebulized, Admit if severe

clinicalPearls: Silent chest in acute asthma indicates life-threatening severity
ICS are cornerstone of chronic management, reduce exacerbations
Never use LABA as monotherapy (increases mortality)
Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD): Asthma + nasal polyps + aspirin sensitivity
Check inhaler technique at every visit

practiceQuestions.question: A 25-year-old with known asthma presents with severe dyspnea, unable to complete sentences, RR 32, HR 125, silent chest on auscultation. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
options: Oxygen, nebulized bronchodilators, IV steroids, consider ICU
practiceQuestions.explanation: This is life-threatening asthma (silent chest, inability to speak, tachypnea, tachycardia). Requires aggressive management with high-flow oxygen, continuous nebulized bronchodilators, IV steroids, and ICU consideration for possible intubation.

topics.title: COPD
keyPoints: Progressive airflow limitation due to chronic bronchitis and/or emphysema
Main risk factor: Smoking (>20 pack-years), also biomass fuel, alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
Chronic bronchitis: Productive cough for ≥3 months in 2 consecutive years
Emphysema: Destruction of alveolar walls → air trapping, hyperinflation
Clinical features: Progressive dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production, wheeze, barrel chest
Diagnosis: Post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC <0.7 on spirometry
GOLD classification: Mild (FEV1 ≥80%), Moderate (50-79%), Severe (30-49%), Very severe (<30%)
Stable COPD: SABA/SAMA PRN → LABA/LAMA → LABA+LAMA → add ICS if frequent exacerbations
Acute exacerbation: Increased dyspnea, sputum volume/purulence → Oxygen (target 88-92%), nebulized bronchodilators, steroids, antibiotics if purulent
Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT): If PaO2 <55 mmHg or <60 with cor pulmonale, improves survival

mnemonics.COPD: Features - Cough, Obstruction, Pink puffer/Blue bloater, Dyspnea
mnemonics.GOLD: Severity grading - Grade 1-4 based on FEV1

clinicalPearls: Avoid high-flow oxygen in COPD (risk of CO2 retention), target SpO2 88-92%
ICS increases pneumonia risk in COPD, use only if frequent exacerbations
Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Early-onset emphysema, lower lobe predominant
Smoking cessation is the only intervention that slows FEV1 decline
NIV indicated if pH <7.35 despite optimal medical therapy

practiceQuestions.question: A 65-year-old smoker with COPD presents with increased dyspnea and purulent sputum. ABG shows pH 7.32, PaCO2 65, PaO2 55 on 4L O2. What is the next step?
practiceQuestions.explanation: Acute COPD exacerbation with respiratory acidosis (pH <7.35) despite medical therapy is an indication for NIV (BiPAP). This can prevent intubation and improve outcomes. Increasing oxygen can worsen hypercapnia.

topics.title: Peptic Ulcer Disease
keyPoints: Mucosal break in stomach (gastric ulcer) or duodenum (duodenal ulcer)
Main causes: H. pylori infection (70-90%), NSAIDs, stress (ICU patients)
Duodenal ulcer: Pain 2-3 hours after meals, relieved by food, more common
Gastric ulcer: Pain worsened by food, associated with weight loss
Diagnosis: Upper GI endoscopy with biopsy (rule out malignancy in GU), H. pylori testing (urea breath test, stool antigen, biopsy)
H. pylori eradication: Triple therapy (PPI + Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin) for 14 days OR Quadruple therapy (PPI + Bismuth + Tetracycline + Metronidazole)
NSAID-induced: Stop NSAID, PPI therapy, switch to COX-2 selective if needed
Complications: Bleeding (most common), perforation, gastric outlet obstruction, malignant transformation (GU only)
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome: Gastrinoma → multiple refractory ulcers, diarrhea, high gastrin levels
Confirm eradication: Urea breath test or stool antigen 4-6 weeks after treatment

mnemonics.GASTRIC: Ulcer causes - Gastrinoma, Aspirin/NSAIDs, Smoking, Trauma, Reflux, Infection (H. pylori), Corticosteroids
mnemonics.PACED: PUD complications - Perforation, Anemia, Cancer (GU), Erosion/bleeding, Duodenal obstruction

clinicalPearls: All gastric ulcers need biopsy to rule out malignancy, DU rarely malignant
Posterior DU can erode into gastroduodenal artery → massive bleeding
Anterior DU perforation → pneumoperitoneum (air under diaphragm on CXR)
Triple therapy failure rate increasing due to clarithromycin resistance
PPI should be taken 30 minutes before meals for optimal effect

practiceQuestions.question: A 50-year-old presents with epigastric pain relieved by food. Endoscopy shows duodenal ulcer. H. pylori test positive. What is the most appropriate treatment?
practiceQuestions.explanation: H. pylori-positive duodenal ulcer requires eradication therapy with triple therapy: PPI + Clarithromycin + Amoxicillin for 14 days. This heals the ulcer and prevents recurrence.
